title.native: 鋼の錬金術師 シャンバラを征く者
title.romaji: Hagane no Renkinjutsushi: Shamballa wo Yuku Mono
title.english: Fullmetal Alchemist: The Movie - Conqueror of Shamballa

description:
Munich, Germany, 1923. Two years have passed since Edward Elric was dragged from his own world to ours, leaving behind his country, his friends and his younger brother, Alphonse. Stripped of his alchemical powers, he has been all this time researching rocketry together with Alphonse Heiderich, a young man who resembles his own brother, hoping to one day find a way back home. His efforts so far had proven fruitless, but after lending a hand to a troubled gypsy girl, Edward is thrown in a series of events that can wreak havoc in both worlds. Meanwhile, at his own world, Alphonse Elric ventures deeper into the mysteries of alchemy in search for a way to reunite with his older brother.

(Source: Anime News Network)
synonyms: Gekijyouban Hagane no Renkinjutsushi - Shanbara wo Yuku Mono
Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa
Fullmetal Alchemist: The Conqueror of Shamballa
แขนกลคนแปรธาตุ เดอะมูฟวี่ฝ่ามิติพิชิตแดนสวรรค์
Giả kim thuật sư: Người chinh phục Shamballa

tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

node.description: __Mike McFarland__ is an American voice actor, ADR Director, Script, and Line Producer at Funimation Entertainment.

__Cousin:__ [Aaron Dismuke](https://anilist.co/staff/95254/Aaron-Dismuke)

__Justin Ryan Cook__ is an American voice actor, producer, line producer, ADR director and enginner who works for FUNimation.

A voice actress and producer specializing in televised anime. Harp was hired by FUNimation Entertainment in 2003 to voice the character of Tweedledee in Kiddy Grade. Since then, her work has included Sei in Burst Angel, Sanae in Akira Kurosawa's Samurai 7, Hibari Ginza in Speed Grapher and additional roles in Yu Yu Hakusho, Spiral, Fullmetal Alchemist, Case Closed, Desert Punk, Baki the Grappler, The Galaxy Railways, Negima, and BECK.    Her portrayal as Hibari Ginza in the 2006-2007 release of Speed Grapher won her an award in the ADR Awards as voted by members of the websites Dub Review and Anime on DVD.    Harp is also the inspiration for Aubrey Chorde, one of the main characters in the webcomic Something Positive by her friend R.K. Milholland. He claims he decided to make the comic after she told him to do "something positive" with his life. She currently lives and works in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area of Texas. Her hobbies include knitting, crafts and collecting Hello Kitty Memorabilia. (Wikipedia)

A voice actress and producer specializing in televised anime. Harp was hired by FUNimation Entertainment in 2003 to voice the character of Tweedledee in Kiddy Grade. Since then, her work has included Sei in Burst Angel, Sanae in Akira Kurosawa's Samurai 7, Hibari Ginza in Speed Grapher and additional roles in Yu Yu Hakusho, Spiral, Fullmetal Alchemist, Case Closed, Desert Punk, Baki the Grappler, The Galaxy Railways, Negima, and BECK.    Her portrayal as Hibari Ginza in the 2006-2007 release of Speed Grapher won her an award in the ADR Awards as voted by members of the websites Dub Review and Anime on DVD.    Harp is also the inspiration for Aubrey Chorde, one of the main characters in the webcomic Something Positive by her friend R.K. Milholland. He claims he decided to make the comic after she told him to do "something positive" with his life. She currently lives and works in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area of Texas. Her hobbies include knitting, crafts and collecting Hello Kitty Memorabilia. (Wikipedia)

Her self-portrait is usually that of a bespectacled cow, as she was born and raised in a dairy farm with three older sisters and a younger brother. Arakawa started out as [Etou Hiroyuki's](https://anilist.co/staff/98901/) assistant writer for [Mahoujin Guru Guru](https://anilist.co/manga/34080/) and a friend of [Shakugan no Shana](https://anilist.co/manga/33074/) author [Yashichiro Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99114/). Arakawa's career started with a work titled [STRAY DOG](https://anilist.co/manga/33303/), but she is best known for creating the [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/manga/30025/) world and manga. The author is friends with [Akira Segami](https://anilist.co/staff/97387/).

Due to a lack of real publicity photos of Arakawa, a great sum of her fanbase has no idea what she really looks like, even to this day. There are some scarce pictures of the real Arakawa in the web, but they are very low in quality and are rarely used as reference. Many fans have mistaken photos of [Romi Park](https://anilist.co/staff/95082/Romi-Park), Edward Elric's seiyuu, as photos of Arakawa, because of the set-up in one particular image in which Romi Park poses as a mangaka. Romi Park is known for representing Arakawa in public appearances, in which Arakawa is not able to attend. 

_Awards:_
• 1999: 9th 21st Century Enix Award for "Stray Dog"
• 2003: 49th Shogakukan Manga Award, Shōnen category for "Fullmetal Alchemist"
• 2011: 15th Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize, "New Artist Prize" category.
• 2011: 42nd Seiun Award, "Best Science Fiction Comic" category for "Fullmetal Alchemist"
• 2012: 5th Manga Taishō Award for "Silver Spoon"
• 2012: 58th Shogakukan Manga Award, Shōnen category for "Silver Spoon"
• 2013: 1st Contents Award of Japan Food Culture Grand Prize for "Silver Spoon"
• 2023: 1st Rakuten Kobo's E-Book Manga Award, "I Want to Read it Now! Featured Manga" category for "Yomi no Tsugai"
• 2023: 7th Tsutaya Comic Award for "Yomi no Tsugai"

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

After graduating from Tokyo Designers' Gakuin College, Mizushima joined [Tokyo Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/899/). While doing photography work at the beginning of his career he studied under director of photography [Masahiro Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/174419/). He later went to work for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant, aiming to become a full-fledged director.

Mizushima debuted as an episode director in 1993 on [Kouryuu Densetsu Villgust](https://anilist.co/anime/2049/), aiding the director of the OVA [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/). In 1998, he made his proper directorial debut with [Generator Gawl](https://anilist.co/anime/1022/). He has since gone on to direct numerous shows, among which [Shaman King](https://anilist.co/anime/154/), [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/) and [Oh! Edo Rocket](https://anilist.co/anime/2152/).

He often cites [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) as an anime director that he respects.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oichanmusi) | [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/oichanmusi.bsky.social) | [Website](https://hifumi-inc.co.jp/team/mizushima-seiji/)

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"

[Website](http://www.michiru-oshima.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OshimaMichiru) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/6zqZlqpjrq3op255dF32Fr?autoplay=true)

She is a composer who has worked on several video game, movie, and television titles. Her works include composition for the video games Ico for PlayStation 2, Arc the Lad III, and an orchestral arrangement of a Zelda medley for the Wii and Gamecube game The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess. In addition to video game music, she has composed music for the Godzilla movies and scores for numerous anime television series, including Fullmetal Alchemist (and the motion picure Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa), Queen Emeraldas and Bounen no Xamdou. She was also the composer for a Japanese stage musical adaptation of the classic Hollywood film Roman Holiday.

Ooshima graduated from the Kunitachi College of Music, Department of Music Composition. Afterwards she began her activities as a composer and arranger while in college, and has been involved in making music for movies, commercials, TV programs, animated features, and ambient music. While in college, she released a symphony entitled "Orasho". Through her masterful manipulation of both orchestras and synthesizers, she has attracted attention from various sectors for creating grandiose, dramatic sounds and beautiful melodies. Her awards include the Mainichi Film Contest Award for Best Music, and the 21st, 24th, 26th, 27th, 29th and 30th Japanese Academy Award for Music, and Jackson Hole Film Festival 2007(USA) Best Composer Award.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/増井壮一)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/123099499)

Originating from Studio Annapuru, where he worked under the supervision of [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/). He went independent after leaving the studio in 1991. As a freelancer he worked on numerous works as a key animator and started quickly getting recognized as one of the strongest action animators in the industry.

In 2000, Andou made his debut as an episode director with [Medarot](https://anilist.co/anime/1138/)'s 49th episode, and started gradually shifting his focus from animating to directing and storyboarding episodes himself. He mainly worked on studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/)' productions in the early '00s, and got to direct several episodes of [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/) and [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/). In 2007, he directed [Sword of the Stranger](https://anilist.co/anime/2418/), a film which was also produced by Bones. He has since directed multiple shows for both Bones and [P.A. Works](https://anilist.co/studio/132/).

Noted for his action storyboards. He is also close friends with [Masahiro Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/134126/) and often works with him.

_Note: Not to be confused with older animator [Masahiro Andou](https://anilist.co/staff/155926/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1219713270149341184)

Originating from Studio Comet, where he initially worked as a production assistant. He is friends with, and often collaborates with [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) and both [You](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/) and [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). All three of them worked at Gainax together in the '90s.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sekise10) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yutaka_nakamura) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中村豊_(アニメーター%29)

Yutaka Nakamura graduated from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and first joined studio Ad Cosmo. After switching several studios; from Art Office Sharaku, to Anime Torotoro, to [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), he eventually settled at [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/) with a contract.

Nakamura is considered to be among the best action animators, with his scenes featuring catchy movement and effects. Some of his recognizable traits include camera shaking, blurs, and bending and stretching high-speed objects. His fights are praised for its weighty, intense choreographies that are heavy on impact frames. His signature trait is drawing debris as simple cubes, consequentially named "Yutapon Cubes," which are stylistic and easy to draw. Despite being responsible for popularizing it, Nakamura has stated that he started doing it when he noticed [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) doing it. 

(Source: Animators Wiki)

Affiliated with [Studio Silver](https://anilist.co/studio/6240/). Older brother of [You Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/).

He is known for having reached great expertise in many techniques from realistic animation to digital compositing. This gives him the ability to have full control over his works, often being responsible for the key frames, in-betweens, finishing, photography and backgrounds of the scenes he is in charge of.

His skilled use of coloring and compositing, together with the realistic depiction of movement make his works to be often mistaken for computer generated animation.

**Notable works outside anime:**
~!
- Ghost in the Shell (Video Game, 1997) (OP Key Animation)
- Tales of Phantasia (Video Game, 1998) (Cutscene Director, Animation Director, Key Animation)
- Valkyrie Profile Series (Video Game, 1999-2008) (Character Design, Art Design) 
- Kafu ~Kono Shirabe ga Kimi ni Todokimasu You ni~ (Visual Novel, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography, CG Animation)
- Sakura Wars 3: Paris is Burning? (Video Game, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-Between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Akiiro Renka (Visual Novel, 2005) (OP Director, Animation Character Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Muv-Luv Alternative (Visual Novel, 2006) (Cutscene Mecha Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography) !~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/snjaramaki) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/荒牧伸志) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinji_Aramaki)

Aramaki is one of the leading figures in the industry's CG animation, and is noted for his various design works in numerous anime series such as [Gasaraki](https://anilist.co/anime/782/), [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/) and [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/) among many others.

Influenced by [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), and Star Wars during his junior and senior high school years, he decided to pursue a career in film. One of his first representative works was an independently produced animation titled "Moonstruck Artemis," that he made while part of a manga club during his university days. Aramaki didn't have a special desire to work in the animation industry, but has stated joining it solely because he could draw and the industry had a wide range of options for someone like that. He has also said that the spread of digital technology has made it easier for him to work in both anime and live-action.

In 2004, Aramaki directed [Appleseed](https://anilist.co/anime/54/), a re-interpretation of a [Shirou Masamune](https://anilist.co/staff/97609/) manga by [the same name](https://anilist.co/manga/30668/). Although bashed by critics, the movie was an influential piece in the medium that had great impact on creators around the world. Studio Ghibli co-founder [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/) said the movie would reform the industry.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西村博之_(イラストレーター%29)

Originating from [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/).

A co-founder and a board member of [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Upon graduating from high school, Kawamoto was first employed in the making and designing of precision machinery. During this early period, he became interested in becoming an animator due to the ongoing [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/)'s [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s amateur [Daicon](https://anilist.co/anime/2724/) films. In particular, [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s work was a major influence.

After graduating, he applied for a small sub-contracting studio called Group Donguri and was accepted. In 1986, he made his debut in Yasuhiko's 1986 film [Arion](https://anilist.co/anime/791/). During the production he was mentored by the character designer [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/), with whom he would later work with on multiple occasions, including being her assistant in [Venus Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/544/), which was also written and directed by Yasuhiko. After this Kawamoto worked on numerous series by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), most notably as a character designer on the Gundam entries, [Stardust Memory](https://anilist.co/anime/84/) and [The 08th MS Team](https://anilist.co/anime/81/), as well as the internationally acclaimed [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/).

In 1998, he co-founded Bones with fellow Sunrise staff members [Masahiko Minami](https://anilist.co/staff/101519/) and [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). Some of the more recent works he has provided designs for include [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Ghost Slayers Ayashi](https://anilist.co/anime/1587/), [Noragami](https://anilist.co/anime/20447/) and [Kekkai Sensen](https://anilist.co/anime/20727/).

**Non-anime staff credits:**
~!
- Character Design - "Gigantic Drive" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam A year of War" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam F91 Formula Senki 0122" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Return of Zion" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Senki" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE Be Eliminate Yesterday" (Video game)
- Character Design - "OUT LIVE" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Wonder Project J" (Video game)
- Character Design - "Robot Alchemic Drive" (Video game)
- Assistant Chief Animation Director - "OVER THE MONOCHROME RAINBOW" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Animation Director - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation for "Ghost in the Shell" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam Cross Dimension 0079" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam PERFECT ONE YEAR WAR" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Kidou Senshi Gundam" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Serial Experiments Lain" (Video game)
- Key Animation - "Spiral Zone" (ep 5)!~

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/関口可奈味)

Originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), currently affilaited with [P.A. Works](https://anilist.co/studio/132/).
Affiliated with Kusanagi.

Frequents on [P.A. Works](https://anilist.co/studio/132/)' projects, but is freelance.

Was inspired to become an animator after having seen [Ninku](https://anilist.co/anime/912/).
